The  proposal  comprises  (i)  a  program  cluster  of  two  loans  for  the 
Development Policy Support Program (DPSP), and (ii) a proposed loan 
for the second DPSP (DPSP-2), which is subprogram 1 of the proposed 
cluster,  building  on  the  support  provided  through  the  first  DPSP 
approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  December  2005. 
The  DPSP  series—cofinancing  the  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL) 
series supported by the World Bank and the Government of Japan—is 
embedded  in  the  Government’s  Medium-Term  Development  Plan 
(RPJM)  for  2004–2009.  It  supports  the  broad  goal  of  the  RPJM  to 
stimulate  higher  and  sustainable  economic  growth  (to  7%  average 
annual  growth  by  2009  from  around  4%  prior  to  2004)  and  halve 
poverty (from 16.6% in 2004 to 8.2% by 2009). To achieve these goals, 
DPSP-2 supports wide-ranging reforms in four core areas to (i) improve 
macroeconomic stability and creditworthiness, (ii) promote investments, 
(iii)  strengthen  the  public  financial  management  and  anticorruption 
framework, and (iv) improve the delivery of public services. DPSP-2 is 
proposed  as  a  single  tranche  operation  based  on  a  range  of  up-front 
actions taken by the Government in the core areas.

II. 

THE SECTOR AND MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

A. 

Sector Performance, Issues, and Opportunities  

2. 
In the past few years, Indonesia has provided compelling reasons for a positive outlook, 
as  it  has  become  more  stable,  democratic,  and  increasingly  transparent.  The  concern  is  no 
longer  one  of  recovery,  but  of  accelerating  and  sustaining  real  gross  domestic  product  (GDP) 
growth  at  7–8%  levels,  and  translating  that  into  lower  poverty,  more  jobs,  and  reduced 
vulnerability. The Government’s overall goals are to halve poverty by the end of the decade to 
about  8%,  reduce  unemployment  significantly  from  the  current  high  levels  of  10.4%,  and 
achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  targets.  To  achieve  these  goals,  the 
Government  is  poised  to  pursue  a  pro-growth  agenda,  coupled  with  better  governance  within 
the public administration and improvements in public service delivery. Progress has been made 
on  all  fronts,  albeit  slowly  in  some  areas.  In  particular,  Indonesia  is  in  critical  need  of,  among 
other  things,  continuous  improvements  in  the  investment  climate  and  greater  performance 
orientation  within  the  civil  service.  The  DPSP  cluster  allows  the  Government  to  work  with  the 
development partners in a flexible manner to implement high level macroeconomic and strategic 
reforms,  addressing  constraints  that  impede  growth  and  poverty  reduction  through  committed 
annual engagement that provides predictability of support. As such, its sector coverage is fairly 
broad  and  it  adopts  a  thematic  approach  to  improve  overall  economic  governance.  The  CSP 
provides  for  deeper  sector  level  interventions  sequenced  at  regular  intervals  to  complement 
macroeconomic reform support through the DPSP cluster.  
 
3. 
Sustained Macroeconomic Performance. The economy of Indonesia ended 2005 with 
overall real GDP growth of 5.6%, the best performance to date since the Asian financial crisis. 
Table 1 presents data on key indicators over 2001–2005 that show the continuous recovery and 
restoration of macroeconomic stability. The economy has grown at a steady and sustained pace 
and investor confidence has risen, supported by the bold decision in October 2005 to increase 
fuel  oil  prices  by  126%.  The  efforts  and  commitment  to  implement  structural  reforms,  and 
effective  coordination  between  the  Government  and  Bank  Indonesia  (BI),  have  significantly 
improved  market  confidence,  taking  the  rupiah  to  its  strongest  level  in  2  years  and  the  stock 
market  to  record  high  levels.  The  rupiah  appreciated  by  about  8%  over  January–September 
2006 to Rp9,100 per $, and the Jakarta Stock Index posted a 24% gain to 1,460 over the same 
period. Citing an improved policy environment, Moody’s raised Indonesian bond ratings (foreign 
and domestic) from B2 to B1, followed by an upgrade by Standard & Poor’s (S&P) from B+ to 
BB-  in  July.  However,  Moody’s  rating  is  still  four  levels  from  investment  grade  and  the  S&P 
rating three levels below investment grade.

management. The central government budget deficit stood at 0.5% of GDP at the end of 2005, 
and the public debt-to-GDP ratio improved to 47% (down from 55% in 2004 and 100% in 1999). 
Indonesia’s  debt-to-GDP  ratio  is  now  quite  close  to  the  level  in  Malaysia  (45.7%);  Thailand 
(26.1%) is considerably lower, but the Philippines (72.3%) is much higher. While the declining

GDP ratio, it also reflects low spending in early 2005, especially on capital projects.   
 
6. 
With the fiscal space generated by the fuel subsidy reduction, the Government should be 
able to scale up public investment from the current level of 5% of GDP to about 7% by 2008—a 
level matching the pre-crisis period. The Government and parliament have agreed to increase 
the  budget  deficit  target  for  2006  from  0.7%  in  the  approved  budget  to  1.1%  to  help  meet: 
(i) expenditures  related  to  the  Yogyakarta  earthquake,  (ii)  additional  expenditures  on  cash 
transfers  to  the  poor  to  cushion  the  impact  of  the  fuel  price  increases,  and  (iii)  the  higher 
electricity  subsidy  payments  to  the  State  Electricity  Corporation  (PLN),  necessitated  by  last 
year’s doubling of fuel prices (para.29 below). The revised 2006 and new 2007 budgets project 
continued  higher  revenues  and  expenditures.  The  2007  budget  predicts  a  deficit  of  1.1%  of 
GDP with rising non-oil and gas taxes (from 13.6% to 14.4% of GDP) and continued spending at 
21.6%  of  GDP,  as  the  impact  of  high  oil  prices  continues  to  be  felt.  For  example,  capital 
spending remains at just over 2% of GDP in 2007 (from 1.2% in 2005).  
 
7.

5.6% of GDP in 2005. These expenditure increases are the effect of higher oil prices and allow

Translating  Growth  into  Equity  and  Efficiency—Progress  on  the  Governance 
Front.  Indonesia  has  made  significant  progress  in  improving  governance  since  the  crisis,  but 
particularly over the last 2 years. Legal reforms on elections and decentralization have resulted 
in greater transparency and political accountability. There is open public debate on a wide range 
of issues, including the Government’s performance, quality of public administration, corruption, 
and  provision  of  government  support  to  the  private  sector.  The  Government’s  openness  and 
commitment to fighting corruption has been noteworthy. It has established and strengthened a 
range  of  independent  oversight  and  judicial  institutions  such  as  the  Corruption  Eradication 
Commission,  Anti-Corruption  Court,  Judicial  Commission,  Police  Commission,  and 
Prosecutorial Commission. The capacity and role of other independent institutions such as the 
Supreme  Audit  Institution  (BPK),  Financial  Transactions  Analysis  and  Tracking  Center,  and 
Attorney General’s Office—all of which receive or have received significant ADB support—have 
also  been  strengthened.  The  Government  has  launched  various  high  profile  corruption 
investigations, leading to several successful prosecutions. 
 
12. 
Nevertheless,  the  approach  taken  to  date  has  been  more  reactive  than  proactive.  The 
initial  zeal  in  the  prosecution  of  high  profile  cases  has  not  yet  translated  into  a  systematic 
approach for combating corruption. While the President has taken anticorruption seriously, there 
has  been  no  effective  bridge  to  reduce  the  significant  disconnect  between  the  new  vision  and 
the old way of doing business in most of the line ministries and other public sector agencies. An 
anticorruption  package  was  adopted  through  Presidential  Instruction  No.  5/2005  in  February 
2005, soon after the new Government took power. With over 100 action plans, the package was

Other Recent Developments. Indonesia remains vulnerable to natural calamities. Just 
as  the  reconstruction  process  was  beginning  to  gear  up  in  Aceh  and  Nias,  Yogyakarta, 
Central Java  and  West  Java  faced  another  round  of  devastating  earthquakes  and  a  tsunami. 
The  loss  of  over  6,000  lives  in  Yogyakarta  and  Central  Java  in  late  May  2006  and  another 
600 lives in West Java in late July has challenged the Government and development partners. 
Yet,  the  response  has  been  swift  and  commendable.  The  other  major  challenge  facing 
Indonesia is the spread of avian flu and the continuing risks of bird-to-human transmission, with 
44  human  deaths  as  of  mid-September  2006.  Recently,  after  significant  delays,  there  is  an 
agreement within the Government on a detailed action plan. A program of $250 million per year, 
jointly funded by the Government and the international community, is being put in place. A multi-
donor Java Reconstruction Fund is in the final stages of establishment to channel contributions 
from various donor countries for the rehabilitation and reconstruction process.

27. 
General  Progress  and  Constraints  under  Core  Policy  Area  I.  As  outlined  earlier 
(paras.2-6), Indonesia has been quite successful in restoring and reestablishing macroeconomic 
stability  since  the  Asian  financial  crisis.  In  particular,  successive  administrations  have  focused 
on  fiscal  consolidation  and  monetary  stability,  and  paved  the  way  for  some  key  structural 
reforms.  The  first  phase  of  the  DPL  supported  the  adoption  and  implementation  of  the  white 
paper  reforms,  with  ADB  engagement  through  several  parallel  operations  (footnote  3). 
Subsequently,  the  hallmark  of  macroeconomic  management  during  DPSP-1  was  the  bold 
decision  to  increase  domestic  fuel  prices,  reflecting  strong  government  commitment  despite 
short-term pain. As a result of the adjustments, there was an additional fiscal space of $5 billion 
in  2005  and  approximately  $10  billion  in  2006.  This  could  enable  one  of  the  largest  public 
expenditure reorientations in recent history in any country toward higher priority social areas. 
 
28. 
At  a  broader  level,  many  indicators  have  improved  in  recent  years.  Most  noteworthy 
have  been  improvements  in  market  perception,  demonstrated  through  (i)  upgrading  of 
international credit ratings; (ii) the significant decline in public debt-to-GDP ratio by almost 20% 
from about 64% in 2003 to 45% in mid-2006; and (iii) the significant shift in revenue sources, as 
domestic non-oil and gas revenues are projected to comprise about 13.6% in 2006, from 10.4% 
in 2003. These underlie the stable recovery of Indonesia’s economy toward one of the highest 
growth rates among similarly sized economies in the region. As a result of these outcomes, the 
Government and the development partners have agreed that the next phase of DPSP (DPSP-3 
and DPL-4) will continue the policy dialogue on macroeconomic stability but with the intention of 
eliminating  the  separate  pillar  focused  on  these  issues.  This  decision  testifies  to  the  general 
confidence in the Government’s commitment to sound macroeconomic management, based on 
a convincing track record.   
 
Despite these positive outcomes, the Government needs to address a number of other

a. 

Improving Fiscal Policy 

31. 
Key Issues. The overriding objective of the Government’s fiscal reform efforts has been 
to  enhance  the  amount  and  predictability  of  tax  revenues  through  improved  compliance  and 
broadening the tax base, while reducing tax rates to improve investment sentiment. In the past 
several years, the Government has  increased taxpayer registration and filing of tax returns by 
new  and  existing  taxpayers,  and  has  improved  recovery  of  tax  arrears  and  expanded  audit 
coverage.  In  December  2004,  electronic  registration  of  taxpayers  was  introduced,  as  was 
electronic  filing  in  January  2005.  Earlier  support  through  the  DPL  has  facilitated  the 
modernization of tax offices, including upgrading facilities and information technology systems, 
staff  reorganization  by  function,  increased  remuneration,  and  the  institution  of  taxpayer  bill  of 
rights and tax official code of conduct. The extension of modern tax offices continued in 2006, 
with a major expansion to medium sized tax offices in Indonesia, and through the beginning of a 
reorganization of the central tax office to support the longer-term tax reform agenda (core policy 
area 3). 
 
32. 
However,  many  problems  remain  despite  progress  in  extending  the  modern  tax  office 
system.  The  tax  system  is  still  characterized  by  relatively  low  revenue  generation,  poorly 
defined and overly complicated taxes (i.e., creating excessive compliance costs), and poor and 
inconsistent  enforcement  (i.e.,  creating  uncertainty  and  abuse).  The  problem  requires  better 
oversight of tax officials, and partly stems from a systematic lack of information and capacity for 
tax  and  customs  analysis  outside  tax  and  customs  offices.  The  lack  of  capacity  has  led  to  an 
inability  to  accurately  assess  and  forecast  the  implications  of  proposed  tax  and  customs 
changes; reduced checks and balances; and an imbalance between taxpayer and government 
requirements.

Accomplishments. There has been no coherent legal framework governing the regional 
government-owned enterprises (BUMDs), and the law on national state-owned enterprises does 
not  focus  on  BUMDs.  The  Ministry  of  Home  Affairs  has  now  coordinated  the  finalization  of  a

Trigger 1. Fiscal Policy. The Government of Indonesia (the Government) established a 
1. 
Financial  Management  Reform  Committee  in  2002  to  help  prepare  a  comprehensive 
restructuring of the institutional and legal architecture for fiscal management in Indonesia. The 
committee  accomplished  two  key  outputs.  The  first  was  to  enact  the  laws  to  strengthen  fiscal 
management:  (i)  Law  on  State  Finance  (Law  No.  17/2003),  (ii)  Law  on  State  Treasury

budget,  the  Agency  for  Economic  and  Fiscal  Research  became  operational,  and  the  financial 
sector supervision functions moved to a separate agency. The broader thrust behind both steps 
has  been  supported  by  the  Development  Policy  Loan  (DPL)/DPSP  process.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) has supported in a number of related aspects, most notably a human 
resource  assessment  of  MOF, 
facilitating  Financial  Management  Reform  Committee’s 
diagnostics. ADB also provided inputs to the laws and the related regulations. The World Bank 
has supported through the formulation of its Government Financial Management and Revenue 
Administration Project.  
 
2. 
Trigger  2.  Debt  Management.  Fiscal  consolidation  has  been  the  hallmark  of 
macroeconomic management in Indonesia. A key part of this has been continuous improvement 
in debt management, an outcome supported by the DPL process. By the end of 2005, the ratio 
of  debt  to  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  had  dropped  to  47%,  from  55%  in  2004  and  over 
100% in 1999. Even with the ongoing scaling up in public spending on education, health, and 
infrastructure—and  the  resulting  higher  fiscal  deficit  of  –1.1%  as  envisaged  in  the  2006 
budget—fiscal  sustainability  should  not  be  affected  as  long  as  international  oil  prices  remain 
relatively high. With this, the debt-to-GDP ratio is projected to fall below 30% in 2010. Under the 
first phase of DPSP/DPL-2, the Government adopted and began the implementation of a debt 
management  strategy  (MOF  Decree  No.  06/2005),  which  was  presented  to  parliament  in 
September  2005.  The  strategy  outlined  the  risks  to  central  government  debt,  the  instruments 
currently  available,  and  provided  direction  for  decisions  on  borrowing  and  buybacks.  DPSP-2 
aims to deepen this support.

This has been a transformative year for Indonesia. The difficult adjustment to last year’s higher 
fuel prices and interest rates is ending with improved macroeconomic stability and accelerating 
growth. These policy steps were needed to return confidence and put fiscal-monetary policy on a 
sounder footing, thus providing the basis for sustained GDP growth and poverty alleviation over 
the long term. Along with the economic adjustment, the past year has seen more natural disasters, 
heightened concerns over avian influenza, and continued vulnerability among a large segment of 
Indonesia’s  people.  Despite  these  challenges,  the  Government  has  pushed  through  its  reform 
program with stepped up efforts in priority areas, including the investment climate, the financial 
sector; infrastructure; governance, anti-corruption, and civil service; and service delivery, social 
protection, and social inclusion through community-driven approaches.

New initiatives and policy packages in the areas mentioned above aim to complement our broad-
based medium-term development plan (or RPJM) – which seeks to reduce poverty in half, to 8.2

poverty  and  disparity;  (2)  enhancement  of  job  opportunities,  investment  and  exports;  (3) 
revitalization of agriculture and rural investment; (4) enhancement of accessibility and quality of

Maintaining Macroeconomic Stability 

In  the  area  of  macroeconomic  stability,  Indonesia  has  had  good  success  over  recent  years.  The 
economy  appears  to  have  successfully  weathered  the  October  2005  fuel  price  increase,  the 
currency volatility that preceded it, and the economic slowdown that followed. GDP growth has 
rebounded in the second-half of 2006. Falling from a strong 6 percent in early-2005 to 5.5-5.7 for 
the year, growth bottomed out to 4.7 percent in the first quarter of 2006 before climbing to 5.2 
percent in the second quarter. We now project growth to exceed 6 percent by the fourth quarter of 
2006.  Improved  economic  indicators  have  helped  bolster  consumer  and  market  confidence,  as 
well  as  improved  market  credit  ratings.  Indonesia’s  credit  ratings  continue  to  improve,  with 
Moody’s  moving  from  B2  to  B1  in  May  and  S&P  from  B+  to  BB-  in  July.  The  stock  market 
reached historic highs and now stands over 30 percent above its level in January this year. Lastly, 
capital imports, which were weak during the first half of 2006, reached their highest in nine years 
in  August  and  September  2006.  These  indicators,  coupled  with  increased  Government  and 
consumer  spending,  and  strong  exports,  are  driving  current  economic  growth.  Investments, 
however, have shown some decline. With improved macroeconomic fundamentals, we are laying 
a stronger foundation for sustained growth over the long term.   
 
The  Government  and  monetary  authority  has  been  very  successful  in  controlling  inflation. 
Interest rates are now declining at all maturities and are approaching historical lows at the long 
end of the curve. Year-on-year inflation has fallen from over 17 percent by the end of 2005 to 6.3 
percent in October 2006, and we expect inflation will end the year well below the low end of the 
Central Bank’s inflation target range of 7 to 9 percent, setting the stage for further reductions next 
year. The Government will continue to work with the Central Bank on the medium-term goal of 
bringing  inflation  in  line  with  that  of  neighboring  countries,  as  we  believe  that  this  will  add 
additional  stability  to  our  exchange  rate  and  reduce  the  current  premium  built  into  Indonesia’s 
real interest rate, which will further spur investment.

Staff Assessment of Developments and Policies 

 
Recent Developments and Short-Term Prospects 
 
After  the  recent  slowdown,  GDP  growth  has  begun  to  recover.  Following  the  significant  hike  in 
interest rates and fuel price increases in the fall of 2005, real GDP growth slowed to under 5 percent in 
the last quarter of 2005 and first quarter of 2006 (y/y). However, growth picked up to 5.2 percent (y/y) in 
the  second  quarter,  mainly  reflecting  strong  external  demand  and  some  acceleration  in  public 
consumption.  Though  still  weak,  private  consumption  appears  to  be  picking  up,  indicating  that  the 
adjustment  to  the  domestic  fuel  price  hike  last  fall  is  nearly  complete.  Nevertheless,  unemployment  is 
edging up and poverty rates remain high. Growth is expected to pick up gradually over the course of 2006 
and in 2007, with IMF staff projecting annual growth to reach 5.2 percent and 6 percent, respectively, as 
interest rates are reduced. Nevertheless, there are risks to this outlook, most importantly a weakening of 
the international environment and slow implementation of structural reforms.  

Inflationary  pressures  have  been  declining.  Headline  inflation  declined  to  14.6  percent  (y/y)  in 
September, from 17.1 percent at end-2005, reflecting weak activity and some appreciation of the rupiah. 
Meanwhile,  three-month  annualized  inflation  (both  headline  and  core)  has  remained  below  6  percent 
since the beginning of the year. On current trends, Bank Indonesia’s (BI’s) end-year target of 7–9 percent 
for headline inflation is well within reach.  

The  overall  banking  sector  continues  to  perform  reasonably  well.  Partly  due  to  reclassification, 
nonperforming loans (NPLs) increased substantially in 2005, especially at the two largest state banks, but 
the rise in NPLs moderated in January–June 2006. The sharp deceleration in credit growth in 2006, as a 
result of high interest rates and weak demand, will to some extent undermine bank profitability, but the 
expected reduction in interest rates should prevent excessive adverse effects on banks. Capital adequacy 
ratios remain at over 20 percent. 

External vulnerabilities continue to be reduced. The current account is expected to remain in surplus in 
2006. Foreign exchange reserves, at about $39 billion after the repayment of remaining debt to the Fund 
of $3¼ billion on October 12, are equivalent to about 130 percent of short-term debt. The current account 
is expected to move into small deficit over the medium term as imports rise faster than exports, financed 
in large part by private sector capital inflows. The ratio of external debt to GDP is expected to be reduced 
to below 25 percent of GDP in 2011, from 48 percent of GDP in 2005. Nevertheless, the market volatility 
experienced in May/June 2006 is a reminder that Indonesia remains susceptible to adverse developments 
in international capital markets.

The budgeted policy stance is broadly appropriate. The fiscal deficit targets of 1.3 percent of GDP for 
2006 and 0.9 percent of GDP for 2007, as outlined in the President’s budget speech in mid-August, are 
appropriately geared to further reducing the debt burden, to below 30 percent in 2010 (compared with 47 
percent at end 2005), while supporting activity in 2006. After considerable under spending in 2005 and 
the first quarter of 2006, budget execution improved in the second quarter of 2006. 

Monetary policy continues to be geared to reducing inflation. BI’s gradual approach to reducing its 
policy rate has helped contain inflationary pressures and increase foreign exchange reserves. There should 
be  room  for  further  gradual  rate  cuts  given  the  benign  inflation  outlook  and  still  large  differential  with 
U.S.  interest  rates,  though  the  authorities  need  to  be  careful  that  excessive  rate  decreases  do  not 
undermine  their  credibility  and  prospects  for  achieving  the  2007  inflation  target  of  5–7  percent.  The 
clarity  and  consistency  of  statements  by  BI  officials  in  signaling  the  central  bank’s  policy  intentions, 
within the inflation targeting framework, has improved and is essential to maintaining credibility.  

Steps  are  being  taken  to  deal  with  NPLs  at  state  banks.  The  recently  signed  Presidential  decree 
allowing state banks to provide haircuts on loans, together with stepped-up efforts to enforce collections, 
should help to resolve the NPL problem, and avoid erosion of bank capital. IMF staff continue to advise 
that medium-term strategies be adopted for the state banks, which should involve privatizing those that do 
not have a clear public policy objective. As regards private banks, supervisors will need to remain vigilant 
to enforce regulations, and to monitor any deterioration in credit quality.  

The government is proceeding on a broad range of fiscal reforms. Adoption of the tax package now 
before Parliament, along the lines endorsed by the business community, as well as modernization of the 
tax  department,  will  help  enhance  revenue  collection  while  restoring  investor  confidence.  The 
government’s  intention  to  better  manage  potential  risks  stemming  from  the  operations  of  public 
enterprises and private-public partnerships is welcome. 

To  improve  the  business  climate  and  boost  growth,  the  government  has  prepared  an  impressive 
reform  agenda.  Given  the  business  community’s  concerns  about  implementation,  some  major  early 
reform  successes  are  needed  to  increase  confidence  that  the  entire  package  will  be  implemented.  The 
government’s efforts to secure early approval of customs, investment, and tax laws are welcome, which 
apart from the signaling effect would also bring immediate benefits for trade and investment. 

Fund  staff  recognizes  the  difficulties  of  amending  labor  legislation.  Staff  supports  the  authorities’ 
intention to press ahead with the introduction of regulations that ensure a balanced framework for labor-
business relations. The new regulations need to protect the rights of workers, while enhancing flexibility 
for business, in particular with regard to severance pay and outsourcing requirements. More flexible labor 
markets  will  help  Indonesia  become  more  competitive  vis-à-vis  neighboring  countries  and  should 
encourage employers to make hiring decisions more freely.

FIDUCIARY ASSESSMENT 

BACKGROUND 
 
This assessment of fiduciary aspects of the loan has drawn upon several studies undertaken by 
the  development  partners  on  public  financial  management  (PFM)  and  accountability  that  have 
been completed over the last 12 months. Studies undertaken internally within the World Bank include a 
review  of  the  progress  made  in  implementing  the  second  DPL  approved  in  year  2005  (in  collaboration 
with  ADB  and  the  Government  of  Japan),  the  results  of  a  supervision  mission  to  assess  progress  in 
implementing the World Bank-financed Government Financial Management and Revenue Administration 
Project  (GFMRAP)  that  became  effective  in  October  2005,  a  review  of  the  developments  in  the  audit 
sector and the findings of a Public Expenditure Review completed this year. Other key inputs include the 
implementation  reports  on  the  ongoing  State  Audit  Reform  Program  and  Project  –  being  implemented 
with  ADB  support  -  and  a  recent  report  by  IMF  on  Observance  of  Standards  and  Codes  on  Fiscal 
Transparency.  These  provide  the  analytical  underpinnings  for  PFM  and  fiduciary  assessments  for  this 
operation. 

The  reform  agenda  is  clearly  being  led  by  the  Government,  with  support  from  several  donor  agencies, 
and has consistently received good support under the current Government that has been in office for two 
years. Deficiencies in Indonesia’s PFM systems have been well documented in recent years and a reform 
program to address these was formulated by the Government in their White Paper on PFM reforms that 
was prepared in 2002. This reform program included, amongst others, the following main areas: 

•  Modernizing  an  outdated  legal  environment  for  PFM,  by  issuing  a  modern  set  of  laws  and 

implementing regulations; 

•  Reforming  an  opaque  and  inefficient  budget  formulation  process,  by  discontinuing  the  separate 
recurrent  and  development  budgets,  and  introducing  performance  budgeting  systems  and 
forward estimates; 

•  Reforming  budget  implementation,  in  particular  the  inefficient  payments  system  and  weak 

monitoring arrangements; 

•  Modernizing  management  of  the  Government  Treasury,  to  consolidate  fragmented  cash 

management and make government banking arrangements more efficient; 

• 

Introducing modern Government Accounting Standards and accounting practices to improve the 
reliability of Government financial reporting; 

•  Reforming  arrangements  for  government  auditing,  in  particular  strengthening  the  mandate  and 
capacity of Supreme Audit Institution (BPK), addressing overlaps between external and internal 
audit agencies and clarifying their respective roles and responsibilities. 

 
Some  specific  aspects  of  reforms  have  been  supported  under  the  series  of  Development  Policy  Loans 
over the last three years. A commentary on the progress in implementing these reforms is given below to 
help determine the attendant risks arising from the borrower’s capacity to receive and manage this loan 
and  help  determine  the  fiduciary  arrangements  for  this  operation.  A  summary  of  the  specific 
recommendations made under the last CFAA and their current status is also attached. 
 
CURRENT STATUS OF PFM REFORM – A SUMMARY 
 
The more notable achievements accomplished and shortcomings are summarized below. 

A. Regulatory Framework for PFM 
 
Substantial progress has been made in establishing the regulatory framework for improved PFM 
by  the  issue  and  development  of  appropriate  implementing  regulations  under  the  troika  of  laws 
that  were  passed  by  Parliament  during  2003  and  2004,  and  the  other  complementary  laws  on 
Planning and Procurement that were passed during the same period.

The  Law  on  State  Finances  (No.  17/  2003),  although  at  a  high  level  of  generality,  underpins  the 
reform of the Government budgeting process and is currently under implementation. It provides for 
the  first  time  for  such  basic  budget  processes  as  developing  a  macro-economic  and  fiscal  framework, 
establishing a budget timetable, setting out the budget information to be supplied to Parliament and the 
use of internationally recognized classification standards (GFS) in developing the budget. Reforms being 
undertaken in the budget formulation area include the unification of the previous two separate budgets, 
the  development  of  an  MTEF  system  and  the  introduction  of  performance  based  budgeting.  A 
complementary piece of legislation has also been passed, viz., the State Development Planning System 
Law  (2004),  which  provides  the  legal  basis  for  the  national  development  planning  process,  and  for  the 
linking of planning with budgeting. 

 

The  State  Treasury  Law  (No.  1/  2004)  provides  the  basis  for  modernizing  budget  execution  and 
reporting.  Treasury  reforms  being  undertaken  include  steps  to  rationalize  the  current  proliferation  of 
government  bank  accounts  and  to  centralize  cash  management,  simplify  and  speed  up  the  payments 
system,  and  to  improve  reporting  on  budget  execution.  Government  financial  reporting  will  also  be 
improved through the implementation of government accounting standards on a modified accrual basis, 
with an eventual move to full accrual accounting.  
 
The  State  Audit  Law  (No.  15  /  2004)  lays  out  the  broad  legal  framework for  the  operation  on  the 
country’s  supreme  audit  institution,  BPK,1  to  reinforce  its  position  and  mandate  as  an  external 
audit institution equal to but reporting to Parliament. While the audit law takes the important step of 
establishing BPK as the only external auditor and the Supreme Audit Institution in the country, the Law 
does  not  adequately  resolve  some  remaining  conflicts  arising  from  BPK’s  role  nor  does  it  remove 
restrictions on its scope as articulated in some older legislation, for example with respect to BPK’s access 
to  records  of  Tax  Revenues  department.  In  addition,  the  State  Audit  Law  did  not  cover  the  institutional 
arrangements  for  the  management  and  oversight  of  BPK,  for  which  a  separate  law  (BPK  Law)  -  was 
enacted on 16 October 2006 (Law No.15/06). 
 
Procurement  Presidential  Decree  (80/2003)  introduces  many  improvements  in  the  procurement 
regime  in  Indonesia  and  lays  out  a  plan  for  establishing  a  national  policy  formulation  and  oversight 
agency.  An  omnibus  procurement  law  is  envisaged  for  consolidating,  clarifying  and  simplifying  the 
numerous  procurement  rules  and  regulations.  This  law,  currently  under  preparation,  would  further 
strengthen the legal foundation for modernizing public procurement.  
 
An analysis of the recent PFM laws and their implementing regulations indicates that substantial 
progress  has  been  made  in  preparing  and  issuing  the  required  implementing  regulations, 
although  some  draft  regulations  are  pending  formal  release  as  of  the  date  of  this  analysis.  In 
Indonesia, given the traditionally high level of generality in legislation, laws usually require one or more 
Government  Regulations  to  define  and  govern  their  implementation  followed  by  Decrees  from  the 
President  and  or  Ministers  to  establish  the  systems  and  procedures  necessary  for  their  operation.  The 
State Finances Law, Treasury Law and the State Audit Law are no exception.  
 
All  the  main  implementing  regulations  for  the  State  Finance  Law  have  been  issued,  with  the 
exception  of  a  detailed  manual  on  implementing  the  national  budget  (Article  14),  for  which  a  draft  has 
been  prepared  and  is  being  finalized.  The  issued  regulations  include  Government  regulations  on 
Government  Work  Plan,  National  Government  Departments  Annual  Plan  and  Budget  Deficit.  A  set  of 
Ministerial Decrees have also been issued to regulate Regional Borrowings and Adjustment Funds. 
 
With respect to the State Treasury Law, a number of Government Regulations have been issued to 
regulate aspects of budget execution and others are at an advanced stage of preparation. These 
include  specific  financial  management  provisions  for  designated  General  Public  Service  Agencies 
(23/2005),  promulgation  of  Government  Accounting  Standards  (24/2005),  write-off  of  State  receivables 
(14/2005),  State  Asset  Management  (6/2006)  and  Finance  and  Performance  Reporting  (8/2006).  In 
addition,  Ministerial  decrees  have  been  issued  on  aspects  such  as  management  of  inter-governmental

B. Early Experience in Implementing Reforms 
 
The Government has recognized early some key challenges in moving beyond the development of 
appropriate laws and regulations to their effective implementation. As an integral part of the change 
management  process,  the  Government  reorganized  the  Ministry  of  Finance.  This  was  accomplished 
reasonably well during 2005, in particular by creating a new DG Budget and Fiscal Balance and a new 
DG Treasury, broadly in line with earlier IMF recommendations. Both the budget and treasury functions 
have been strengthened by these changes. In particular DG Treasury now oversees all treasury functions 
including cash and debt management, fixed asset management and government fiscal reporting.  
 
Most  recently  in  October  2006,  the  Minister  of  Finance  has  sought  to  further  strengthen  and 
synergize  the  management  of  reforms,  by  setting  up  an  office  for  Policy  Analysis  and 
Harmonization  reporting  directly  to  her.  It  is  anticipated  that  this  office  will  help  expedite  and 
coordinate the completion of the reform agenda.

Budgeting Reforms 
 
New  measures  that  have  been  introduced  through  the  new  State  Finance  Law  are  gradually 
improving  fiscal  transparency.  Budget  documents 
for  2005  and  2006  have  become  more 
comprehensive and informative. These improvements include (i) the new economic and fiscal framework 
(ii)  clearer  expenditure  classification,  including  the  integration  of  routine  and  development  budgets,  and 
presentation of budgets consistent with the GFS 2001. 

Planning  and  budgeting  functions  have  also  been  clarified,  although  more  needs  to  be  done  to 
improve qualitative aspects and improve coordination between Bappenas and Ministry of Finance. 
Planning  and  budgeting  have  been  integrated  by  formally  linking  line  ministry  work  plans  with  budgets. 
The respective roles of BAPPENAS and MOF in budget preparation have been clarified, with BAPPENAS 
assuming full responsibility for the planning process (including preparation of the work plans) and MOF 
having the leading role in the formulation of the annual budget. However, early experience suggests that 
there is a need to further strengthen cross agency coordination between BAPPENAS, MOF and the line 
ministries  to  facilitate  the  move  to  performance  based  budgeting  process.  Improvements  include  the 
timely  submission  of  budgets  to  Parliament  within  the  budget  cycle,  although  there  are  persistent 
concerns about the quality of performance budgets submitted by Line Ministries. The implementation of 
the  MTEF  has  not  been  very  effective  to  date  and  will  require  more  intensive  training  and  wider 
dissemination of the concept. 
 
Some specific implementation experience during 2005 and 2006 is highlighted below: 
 
a. A new functional and program classification consistent with the IMF GFSM 2001 for cash based 
transactions has been implemented. Budget allocations have begun to be based on sector strategies and 
programs rather than historical expenditures. However the program classification requires further review 
to ensure it adequately reflects the objectives of or the program management approach used by individual 
spending ministries.  
 
b.  The  earlier  model  of  separate  recurrent  and  development  budgets  have  now  been  formally 
unified, with components from the former development budget reclassified to the appropriate economic 
categories.  However,  unification  of  the  underlying  substance  of  these  two  groups  may  not  be  entirely 
consistent in all agencies. 
 
c. Progress in implementing MTEF has been limited. Forward estimates have been introduced for the 
first time, although much more work needs to be done to fully adopt the MTEF approach. The Work Plan 
regulations provide for indicative budget ceilings to be issued for two years out but in the 2006 budgets 
indicative ceilings have been issued only for the forthcoming budget year.  
 
d. There has been limited progress in developing a more performance oriented budget. Although a 
start was made with the fiscal 2005 budget, full implementation will take more time as there appears to be 
limited  understanding  and  no  clear  strategy  yet  developed  to  operationalize  this  concept.  Spending 
ministries do not appear to fully understand the objectives of the new work plans and budget documents 
and  so  far  these  appear  to  have  been  an  extensive  paper  exercise  with  little  discernible  impact  on 
resource  allocation.  Strong  collaboration  between  DG  Budget  and  Bappenas  is  needed,  ensuring  that 
they act collaboratively and consistently and that planning is fully integrated into the budget as envisaged 
under performance budgeting.  
 
e.  Severe  delays  were  experienced  in  issuing  budget  authorization  documents  (DIPA)  in  2005, 
although significant improvements were made in 2006. In the past years, these documents were often 
made available to line agencies not until after April of the running year. As a result, a high proportion of 
the  total  funding  provided  under  the  approved  budget  to  spending  agencies  could  not  be  executed  or 
disbursed until the last quarter of the fiscal year. Often virtually no such commitments or disbursements 
could  occur  in  the  first  two  quarters  other  than  purely  routine  expenditure  (such  as  salaries  of  civil 
servants).

The  implementation  experience  with  Budget  execution  processes  is  less  satisfactory,  with  a

a. 
Introduction of a Treasury Single Account (TSA) and automation of the treasury payments 
system are key reforms and progress in pilot testing of the underlying concepts has been slow.

minimizing  central  government  idle  cash/cash  float,  reducing  maintenance  cost  of  too  many  accounts, 
facilitating  cash  forecasting  and  cash  management  control,  as  well  as  enhancing  transparency  and 
accountability of central government banking.   

Pilots for zero balance transitory accounts have been completed in three locations: Jakarta, Bekasi 
and  Batam  since  2005.  Expansion  and  roll-out  of  the  pilot  are  on  hold  due  to  delays  in  passage  and

Internal audit and Controls 
 
The mandates of the three internal audit institutions continue to be unclear as is the allocation of 
resources  between  them.  Internal  audit  is  within the  remit  of  the  BPKP,  the  Inspector  General  (IG) of 
each  ministry,  and  the  Bawasdas  of  municipalities  and  regional  governments.  Ironically,  even  with  (or 
perhaps because of) multiple internal audit agencies in existence, the internal audit function continues to 
be a chronically weak link in governance. 
 
At present the BPKP’s mandate is unclear. It can assist IGs, municipalities and regions upon invitation, 
it  provides  training  in  auditing  for  these  entities.  Although  its  mandate  has  reduced  significantly,  it 
maintains  fully  staffed  decentralized  offices  in  some  26  provinces  in  the  country.  A  key  regulation  on 
internal controls under the State Audit Law (Law No.15/2004) – being supported by ADB as part of the 
STAR  Program  –  deals  with  addressing  the  inconsistencies.  It  is  expected  to  clarify  the  roles  and 
responsibility of BPKP versus the other internal control organs of the Government. In the meantime, the 
enactment  of  the  Law  on  the  Supreme  Audit  Institution  Law  (BPK  Law  No.15/2006)  –  passed  by 
Parliament  on  30  October  2006  –  has  given  the  much  needed  boost  to  clarify  BPK’s  position  and 
authority. 
 
The  IGs  have  different  roles  in  different  ministries.  Their  actual  mandate,  staffing  and  activities  are 
determined  by  the  minister  in  charge  of  the  ministry  in  which  they  operate.  The  IGs  are  therefore  not 
operating  as  one  institution,  but  rather  as  20  institutions  corresponding  to  the  number  of  ministries  and 
ministers.  Generally  they  focus  on  routine  technical  and  performance  audits  (including  compliance  with 
technical standards) conducted on a random basis or in accordance with an approved annual audit plan, 
but  not  on  a  risk  based  methodology.  Reports  are  not  available  to  the  public  or  the  DPR.  Professional 
backgrounds of staff IG therefore normally include technical qualifications and not accounting or auditing. 
 
The  audit  of  financial  transactions  in  the  35  provinces,  442  districts  and  2  regencies  are 
undertaken  in  a  very  complex  institutional  set  up.  The  BPK  is  the  external  auditor  of  all  local 
governments. In each district and province a Bawasda is established to undertake what they call ‘general’ 
audit  of  regional  budget  expenditure.  However,  Bawasda’s  generally  do  not  have  the  skills  of  staff  to 
undertake all audit responsibilities.  
 
The allocation of resources between the internal audit institutions is unclear and there does not 
seem  to  be  strong  cooperation  and  coordination  between  them.  This  hampers  the  realization  of 
synergies between the institutions. The audit of local governments in particularly lacks transparency and 
is needlessly complex.

Procurement Policy 

The  issuance  of  Presidential  Decree  (80/2003)  promotes  the  basic  principles  of  procurement: 
transparency, open and fair competition, economy, and efficiency. It covers all areas of procurement that 
use public funds and contracting entities at all levels of government. The decree meets most of what is 
generally  regarded  as  accepted  international  practice.  However,  the  pace  of  Indonesia’s  commendable 
decentralization  reforms  has  had  an  impact  on  public  sector  procurement  as  different  levels  of 
government  –  from  ministers,  governors,  and  even  mayors  –  are  able  to  issue  their  own  decrees, 
regulations, and instructions. The plethora of regulations is often inconsistent with one another and many 
do  not  meet  accepted  international  practice.  As  a  consequence,  national  procurement  reforms  and  the 
need for national procurement policies and standards have become urgent. One key step in this direction 
is the creation of a National Public Procurement Office (NPPO), which the Government had committed to 
undertaking  in  2001.  However,  progress  has  lagged  in  making  the  NPPO  fully  operational.  The 
Presidential Decree 80/2003 required that the NPPO be established by January 1, 2005. A lot of work has 
already  been  done  and  is  on-going,  in  both  preparing  for  the  establishment  of  the  NPPO  and  also  in 
developing institutional capacity.   

This  measure  however  remains  a  contentious  issue  and  the  Minister  of  Finance  has  stated  that 
many other aspects of the procurement framework could be improved beyond the specific issue 
of  the  NPPO.  For  example,  a  centralized  training  and  procurement  practitioner’s  certification  system  is 
under development with certification at various levels. The system has commenced targeting government 
procurement  practitioners  with  initial  certification  to  the  basic  level  by  means  of  a  computerized  testing 
system.    

Decentralization 

Indonesia has transformed itself from one of the most centralized countries in the world to one of the most 
decentralized countries within a short period of time. In 2004, the regions commanded about 35 percent 
of total Government spending. Given the sharp increase in regional transfers in 2006, the regional share 
in total public investment is likely to rise above  50 percent in 2006. One of the most important pending 
decentralization  reforms  is  on  on-lending  and  on-granting  regulations  and  the  transition  to  market-
oriented system of sub-national credit. The Government has recently issued revisions to on-lending and 
on-granting  decrees  to  facilitate  immediate  support  for  local  infrastructure  finance  and  service  delivery. 
More work is however needed to establish a regulatory framework for the development of more market-
based system of sub-national credit, including the issuance of regional bonds (based on Law 33/2004). 

The BAPPENAS blue book decree has been signed and issued (PerMen PPN No. 5 2006) and the on-
granting and on-lending decrees have been signed by the Minister of Finance.  

Respective roles and responsibilities of MOF and Home Affairs with respect to financial reporting by local 
governments  have  not  been  fully  resolved,  although  some  amendments  to  earlier  decrees  have  been 
made to harmonize local government financial reporting with that applicable to central government.
